data: Funerary inscription for Leontia and Kalliope
Triangular marble plaque. In the lower corners are two menorah and a conic figure, perhaps an ethrog.
Original discovery not recorded; probably from Catania (according to Ferrara and Noy), but possibly from the Monteverde catacomb in Rome (according to Ferrua and Korhonen).
Observed by Torremuzza and Kaibel in Museo Biscari, later by Korhonen in magazzino superiore, collezione Biscari (formerly sala VII, 85)
Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)
Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio

Gabriele Lancillotto Castelli principe di Torremuzza, Siciliae et Objacentium Insularum Veterum Inscriptionum Nova Collectio (Panormus: Excudebat Cajetanus Maria Bentivenga, 1769), http://arachne.uni-koeln.de/books/Castelli1769
Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio prolegomenis et notis illustrata, et iterum cum emendationibus, & auctariis evulgata

Gabriello Lancellotto Castelli Principe di Torremuzza, Siciliae et Objacentium Insularum Veterum Inscriptionum Nova Collectio Prolegomenis et Notis Illustrata, et Iterum Cum Emendationibus, & Auctariis Evulgata, 2nd (1st is 1769) (Palermo: typis regiis, 1784), http://arachne.uni-koeln.de/books/Castelli1784
Storia di Catania sino alla fine del secolo xviii

G. Kaibel, Inscriptiones Graecae Siciliae et Italiae, Additis Graecis Galliae Hispaniae, Britanniae, Germaniae Inscriptionibus, Inscriptiones Graecae Consilio et Auctoritate Academiae Litterarum Regiae Borussicae Editae. Volumen XIV., XIV (Berlin: Georgius Reimerus, 1890)
Le iscrizioni del Museo civico di Catania : storia delle collezioni, cultura epigrafica, edizione
K. Korhonen, Le Iscrizioni Del Museo Civico Di Catania : Storia Delle Collezioni, Cultura Epigrafica, Edizione (Helsinki: Societas Scientiarum Fennica, 2004)
A. Boeckh et al., Corpus Inscriptionum Graecarum, 4 vols. (Berlin: Ex Officina Academica, 1828)
J.-B. Frey and B. Lifshitz, Corpus of Jewish Inscriptions, vol. 1 (New York: Ktav Publishing House, Inc., 1975)
D. Noy, Jewish Inscriptions of Western Europe, 2 vols. (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1993)
Antonio Ferrua, “Osservazioni Sulle Iscrizioni Cristiane Catanesi,” Bollettino Storico Catanese 3 (1938): 60–74
Sicily under the Roman Empire: the archaeology of a Roman province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535
R.J.A. Wilson, Sicily under the Roman Empire: The Archaeology of a Roman Province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535 (Warminster: Aris and Philips, 1990)
Presenze giudaiche nella Sicilia antica e tardoantica
Clara Gebbia, Presenze Giudaiche Nella Sicilia Antica e Tardoantica, Supplementi a Kókalos 11 (Roma, 1996)
K. Korhonen, “Osservazioni sul collezionismo epigrafico siciliano,” Arctos: acta philologica fennica 35 (2001): 85–102
Interaction and its Limits: Some Notes on the Jews of Sicily in Late Antiquity
L.V. Rutgers, “Interaction and Its Limits: Some Notes on the Jews of Sicily in Late Antiquity,” Zeitschrift Für Papyrologie Und Epigraphik 115 (1997): 245–56
funerary inscription for leontia and kalliope
standardisation of template and tidying up encoding
Licensed under a Creative Commons-Attribution 4.0 licence.

Letters with serifs: Α, Δ, Λ with extended serifs, Α with broken bar, lunate Ε, cursive Ω. The supraline indicates the abbreviation of ν. In the lower corner of the stone are two menorah and a conical figure, perhaps an ethrog (a type of citron, used in the festival of Sukkot) or an amphora. According to Ferrare, the symbol can represent a shofar (a small ram's-horn trumpet). Kaibel did not understand this symbol, interpreting it as part of a Υ.
Encoded following the latest EpiDoc guidelines
James Cummings autogenerated EpiDoc output from database
Jonathan Prag made initial revision of the EpiDoc, added translation
Jonathan Prag revised the text division, added Italian translation and commentary
Jonathan Prag added Italian elements and further revised the file
Simona Stoyanova updated list of languages
Marta Fogagnolo revised the text encoding and commentary
Photograph of front face by students of Liceo M.M. Lazzaro, 2017-04-27
Torremuzza and Franz observed only the first epitaph, without the indication of the age
The second menorah is followed by an ethrog (or a shofar according to Ferrara)
Here lies Leontia, aged 3. Here lies Kalliope, aged 18.
Qui giace Leontia di anni 3. Qui giace Calliope di anni 18.

These two Jewish epitaphs may not come from Catania: in describing the Biscari collection, Ferrara gives an imprecise indication of the provenance of this inscription and the structure  is rather typical of the inscriptions from the Monteverde catacombs and not attested elsewhere in Catania. On the provenance, see the discussion in Korhonen 2001: 90-93. In any case, a Jewish community is well attested in Catania, as IMusCatania 228 =  of the 4th cent. AD confirms. The two girls were probably related (perhaps sisters). Both names are attested in the Jewish environment: both Leontia, probably a Jewish translation of Judith attested in CIJ 369 (Rome), and Kalliope, attested in BS II 136, 137, 200 (Beth She’arim, see also the Christian inscriptions of Syracuse IGCVO 948, 1321), however, are also popular among non-Jews (on both names, see Rutgers 1997: 249-250).
ISic001362. Funerary inscription for Leontia and Kalliope

Apparatus criticus

Text based on photographs; Torremuzza and Franz observed only the first epitaph, without the indication of the age; 9: The second menorah is followed by an ethrog (or a shofar according to Ferrara)

English translation

Here lies Leontia, aged 3. Here lies Kalliope, aged 18.

Italian translation

Qui giace Leontia di anni 3. Qui giace Calliope di anni 18.

commentary

These two Jewish epitaphs may not come from Catania: in describing the Biscari collection, Ferrara gives an imprecise indication of the provenance of this inscription and the structure ἔνθαδε κεῖται ὁ δεῖνα ἐτῶν is rather typical of the inscriptions from the Monteverde catacombs and not attested elsewhere in Catania. On the provenance, see the discussion in Korhonen 2001: 90-93. In any case, a Jewish community is well attested in Catania, as IMusCatania 228 = ISic000781 of the 4th cent. AD confirms. The two girls were probably related (perhaps sisters). Both names are attested in the Jewish environment: both Leontia, probably a Jewish translation of Judith attested in CIJ 369 (Rome), and Kalliope, attested in BS II 136, 137, 200 (Beth She’arim, see also the Christian inscriptions of Syracuse IGCVO 948, 1321), however, are also popular among non-Jews (on both names, see Rutgers 1997: 249-250).

On the provenance, see the discussion in Korhonen 2001: 90-93. In any case, a Jewish community is well attested in Catania, as IMusCatania 228 = ISic000781 of the 4th cent. AD confirms. The two girls were probably related (perhaps sisters). Both names are attested in the Jewish environment: both Leontia, probably a Jewish translation of Judith attested in CIJ 369 (Rome), and Kalliope, attested in BS II 136, 137, 200 (Beth She’arim, see also the Christian inscriptions of Syracuse IGCVO 948, 1321), however, are also popular among non-Jews (on both names, see Rutgers 1997: 249-250).
